title: GUI Plugins accessing GuiIface, gui::Events disables gui functions

content.raw:
If a GUI plugin tries to access objects/methods in the gui namespace (`GuiIface` or `gui::Events` are common examples), something fails silently and much of the GUI framework appears to fail. Most notably, `gui::Event`s stop firing and translate, scale, rotate, align, snap and spawn object modes are unavailable.

An example of this bug can be found in branch [issue_1434](#!/osrf/gazebo/branch/issue_1434). Note that if the `gui::get_active_camera()` line is removed, the bug does not appear.

This is the cause of [handsim issue12](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/handsim/issue/12/enable-scale-translate-rotate-mode) and [handsim issue19](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/handsim/issue/19/collapse-sidebar-on-start). `HaptixGUIPlugin` accesses the user camera via `GuiIface::get_active_camera()`, which triggers this bug. In the second issue, we actually make a call to collapse the left pane on startup, but it fails because it is a call to a `gui::Event`, which is disabled by this bug.
content.html:
If a GUI plugin tries to access objects/methods in the gui namespace (GuiIface or gui::Events are common examples), something fails silently and much of the GUI framework appears to fail. Most notably, gui::Events stop firing and translate, scale, rotate, align, snap and spawn object modes are unavailable.

An example of this bug can be found in branch issue_1434. Note that if the gui::get_active_camera() line is removed, the bug does not appear.

This is the cause of handsim issue12 and handsim issue19. HaptixGUIPlugin accesses the user camera via GuiIface::get_active_camera(), which triggers this bug. In the second issue, we actually make a call to collapse the left pane on startup, but it fails because it is a call to a gui::Event, which is disabled by this bug.
